Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Lymph Node Retrieval in Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were patients with mid- and distal-LARC from 16 tertiary centres in China

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients with mid- and distal-LARC from 16 tertiary centres in China, aged 18-70, with specific clinical criteria.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either short-term radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy (TNT group) or long-term concurrent chemotherapy (CRT group)

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the optimal number of lymph nodes (LNs) to retrieve in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC) after total neoadjuvant therapy (TNT) and its impact on survival.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was overall survival (OS), measured from randomisation to death.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated and allocation was concealed via a central trial office.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From 2015 to 2018, 451 patients were analysed, with 227 in the TNT group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patients with limited lymphadenectomy (<11 LNs) had worse OS than those with extended lymphadenectomy (HR 2.95, 95% CI 1.47 to 5.92, P = 0.001).

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Cancer Center/Cancer Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College.
